description: OWASP Top 10 2021 - Attack methods index for bounty hunters

A01.name: Broken Access Control
A01.summary: Access control enforces policy such that users cannot act outside of their intended permissions. Failures lead to unauthorized data disclosure, modification, or destruction.
attack_vectors: Modify URL, internal state, or HTML page
Change primary key to another user's record (IDOR)
Elevation of privilege (act as user without login, act as admin when logged in as user)
Metadata manipulation (replay or tamper JWT, cookie, hidden field)
CORS misconfiguration allowing unauthorized API access
Force browsing to authenticated or privileged pages
form_specific: Hidden field with user ID - change it
Form action URL with object reference - modify it
Select dropdown with limited options - add your own values
Multi-step form - skip steps or go back
hunter_tips: Always check if changing IDs exposes other users' data
Test horizontal (same role) AND vertical (different role) access
Check if deleting your own data lets you delete others'
API endpoints often have weaker access control than UI

A02.name: Cryptographic Failures
A02.summary: Failures related to cryptography which often lead to sensitive data exposure. Previously known as 'Sensitive Data Exposure'.
attack_vectors: Data transmitted in clear text (HTTP, SMTP, FTP)
hunter_tips: Check if password reset tokens are predictable
Look for hardcoded API keys in JavaScript
Test if app accepts HTTP even when HTTPS available
Check if sensitive data appears in browser history/logs

A03.name: Injection
A03.summary: User-supplied data is not validated, filtered, or sanitized. Dynamic queries or commands without context-aware escaping are sent to the interpreter.
form_specific: File upload names - command injection vector
hunter_tips: SQLi in login forms is usually critical severity
Stored XSS pays more than reflected
Always test with encoding variations
Error messages often reveal injection success

A04.name: Insecure Design
A04.summary: Missing or ineffective control design. Insecure design cannot be fixed by perfect implementation - there was never security controls to defend against specific attacks.
attack_vectors: Credential recovery with security questions only
No rate limiting on sensitive operations
Unlimited registration to cause resource exhaustion
form_specific: No CAPTCHA on login (brute force possible)
test_payloads: Set quantity to -1, check if price goes negative
Apply same coupon code multiple times
Register same email with different case
Skip payment step in multi-step checkout
hunter_tips: Business logic bugs often overlooked by scanners
Think about what the developer DIDN'T consider
Race conditions are often insecure design
Look for assumptions that can be violated

A05.name: Security Misconfiguration
A05.summary: Missing appropriate security hardening. Improperly configured permissions, unnecessary features enabled, default accounts/passwords.
keywords: デフォルトパスワード
form_specific: Debug mode exposing form data in errors
test_payloads: Send malformed data to trigger verbose errors
hunter_tips: Check response headers for missing security headers
Directory bruteforce often reveals config files
Default credentials are surprisingly common
Cloud storage misconfigs can be critical

A06.name: Vulnerable and Outdated Components
A06.summary: Using components with known vulnerabilities. Operating systems, web servers, DBMS, APIs, libraries, and all components may be vulnerable.
keywords: 脆弱なコンポーネント
test_payloads: Check server headers for version info
Search CVE databases for known issues
hunter_tips: Chain low-severity CVEs for bigger impact
Frontend libraries often forgotten in updates
Use tools like npm audit, snyk
Check if exploits are available on exploit-db

A07.name: Identification and Authentication Failures
A07.summary: Confirmation of user identity, authentication, and session management is critical. Weaknesses may allow attackers to assume other users' identities.
attack_vectors: Credential stuffing with known breached passwords
form_specific: Remember me token that never expires
Session ID in URL after login
test_payloads: Test if session persists after password change
Check if logout actually invalidates session
hunter_tips: Account takeover via password reset is high severity
Check for username enumeration in login/reset
Test multi-factor authentication bypass
Session tokens should rotate after login

A08.name: Software and Data Integrity Failures
A08.summary: Code and infrastructure that does not protect against integrity violations. Using untrusted sources, insecure CI/CD pipelines, auto-update without verification.
keywords: デシリアライゼーション
form_specific: Serialized session data in hidden fields
Form data processed through unsafe deserializers
hunter_tips: Deserialization bugs can lead to RCE
Check for .NET ViewState, Java serialized objects
PHP unserialize() is often vulnerable
Supply chain attacks are increasingly valuable

A09.name: Security Logging and Monitoring Failures
A09.summary: Without logging and monitoring, breaches cannot be detected. Insufficient logging, detection, monitoring, and active response allows attackers to persist.
attack_vectors: Warnings and errors not generating logs
Logs not monitored for suspicious activity
test_payloads: Generate 100 failed logins, check if blocked
Perform obvious attacks, see if detected
Check if logs are accessible to attackers
hunter_tips: Logging failures are low severity but can upgrade other bugs
Log injection can be chained with other issues
Check if logs expose sensitive data
Missing logging often indicates weak security overall

A10.name: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
A10.summary: SSRF occurs when a web application fetches a remote resource without validating the user-supplied URL. Allows attacker to make requests from the server.
attack_vectors: Fetch internal services via user-supplied URL
Bypass access controls via server trust
hunter_tips: Cloud metadata access often leads to account takeover
SSRF + cloud = potentially critical
Try different protocols and encoding
Blind SSRF can be proven with out-of-band interaction
